title: a font related post - the typ-squerade ball?
content:
Combining fonts, football, F1, \*\*\*\* (cigarettes) and beer...

This Telegraph [article](http://web.archive.org/web/20100704083244/http:/www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2006/07/10/cclife10.xml) on western beers in Russia mentions Heineken's Champions League advertising campaign that used a made up brand "ChapionsPlanet" to circumvent French laws on liquor advertising. The fictional brand uses the distinctive Heine font and colour scheme.

This kind of thing has been going on for years in Formula 1 ( [example](http://web.archive.org/web/20100704083244/http:/www.sporteconomy.it/files/image/foto2005/midlandf1(1).jpg)) to avoid tobacco advertising bans. I've always thought this practice shows the power of typography, and would make for a great magazine article, coffee table book or undergraduate dissertation subject.

Does anyone have any interesting examples of this genre they’d care to share?
author: sii

Chris, I like it - reminds me of this interesting [article](http://web.archive.org/web/20100704083244/http:/www.stltoday.com/stltoday/business/stories.nsf/0/59EA6DBE7B2AF46D86257188000A6619?OpenDocument) on the king'o beers World Cup German/Czech trademark woes.

I can't imagine Bud selling a drop in Germany though. Why would anyone buy a bland beer like Bud when they can get a fine beer from Munich?  
Bud is wiser for opening up the American Hispanic market though. There are many very serious World Cup fans here amomng Spanish speakers in the U.S., Central, and South America.  
I really like the Slovak Pilsner. Try it if you get the chance.

ChrisL
